tossups.question: Both figures are in this position in Munch’s Two Human Beings. Heinrich von Kleist called a work whose title figure is in this position “like the apocalypse.” That work is Monk By the Sea. Magritte put a novel by Poe next to two figures who are oddly both in this position in Not to (*) Be Reproduced. Rückenfiguren are in this position and were the specialty of an artist who painted a man in this orientation holding a walking stick as he looks out over a cliff. For 10 points, give this orientation of the man in Caspar David Friedrich’s Wanderer Above the Sea of Fog.
tossups.answer: facing away from the viewer [accept reasonable descriptions; accept Rückenfiguren until mentioned; prompt on answers like far from the viewer or small or in an imposing landscape from “Heinrich” to “sea” but do not accept or prompt otherwise] <JK>

tossups.question: Giewont is associated with a myth of this type in Polish folklore, and one of these myths provides a Székely [SAY-kay] nickname for the Milky Way and concerns the Hunnic prince Csaba. Another myth of this type concerns Holger Danske and the Kronborg Castle. (*) Drake's Drum is the subject of a myth of this type, while the Kyffhäuser in Germany is associated with one of these myths concerning Frederick Barbarossa. This kind of myth casts Constantine XI as “Marble Emperor.” For 10 points, name this type of myth that gives King Arthur the epithet “the once and future king.”
tossups.answer: King in the mountain [accept King under the mountain; accept Kyffhäuser myth before it is read; accept sleeping hero or sleeping army; accept folklore motif D 1960.2 and tell the player that Tom Hill is buying them a drink; accept any description of the idea of a figure lying dormant in some place with the prospect of returning in a time of need] <HO>

tossups.question: This man held a deadly grudge against the policeman Thomas Lonigan after Lonigan subdued this man in a cobbler’s shop by squeezing his balls. In 2011, bones from a mass grave at Pentridge were confirmed to be this man’s remains. This man sent a lewd note wrapped around calves’ testicles to (*) Jeremiah McCormack’s wife. This perpetrator of the Stringybark Creek murders sent the Jerilderie letter and made a last stand at Glenrowan, where Steve Hart and Joe Byrne were killed. For 10 points, name this Australian outlaw who wore homemade metal armor.
tossups.answer: Ned Kelly <EJW>

tossups.question: One character in this play became a “broken-down man” after moving to a dull provincial town, where he lost the “joy of life”. Another character compares his softening brain to the feel of velvet, and this play ends with him tonelessly repeating “the sun, the sun...” That character in this play turns out to be the (*) half-brother of the woman he loves, the maid Regina. In this play, Engstrand blackmails one character after a fire at an orphanage caused by Pastor Manders. For 10 points, name this work in which Helen Alving cares for her syphilitic son Oswald, by Henrik Ibsen.
tossups.answer: Ghosts [or Gengangere] <JK> DESCRIPTION ACCEPTABLE:

tossups.question: An account of a meeting with William the Welshman in Antwerp suggests that this event occurred later than often believed. Suspects in this event include John Maltravers and Sir Thomas Gurney. Guillaume de Nogaret’s [gee-YOHM-duh-noh-guh-RAY] charges against Boniface VIII, adapted by Adam Orleton, formed the (*) rape-torture narrative of this event. Geoffrey le Baker claimed this event was instigated by Roger Mortimer and Isabella in response to rumours involving Piers Gaveston. For 10 points, identify this event, possibly caused by a red-hot poker in the royal anus.
tossups.answer: The death of Edward II [accept murder of Edward II or any other obvious equivalents that convey the event caused the transition from Edward II being alive to his being dead] <LC>

tossups.question: The north of this country contains a gulf named after Joseph Bonaparte and, in this country, the Spinifex people still practise a hunter-gatherer lifestyle on the largest expanse of limestone bedrock in the world. The world’s longest straight piece of railway crosses that arid area, the(*) Nullarbor plain. A quarter of this country is underlain by the Great Artesian Basin, an important water source in this predominantly arid country that includes the Sturt Stony and Simpson deserts. For 10 points, name this large country, the world’s smallest continent, with capital Canberra.
tossups.answer: Australia <SC>

tossups.question: This is the final principal quantum number of transitions comprising the Humphreys series. The number of normal modes of a non-linear molecule containing N atoms is given by 3N minus this number. The strength of the attractive interaction in the (*) Lennard-Jones potential is inversely proportional to this power of the separation. An atom surrounded by this many substituents can display a trigonal prismatic or octahedral geometry. The p-subshell can hold up to this number of electrons. For 10 points, give this atomic number of carbon.
tossups.answer: six <EM>

tossups.question: One type of these objects is called “Kamuro” for its resemblance to a Japanese boy’s haircut. The largest maker of these objects in the UK was founded by a vicar in the Cambridgeshire village of Kimbolton in 1964. Tubris and gerbs are examples of these objects. Regulations for these objects forbid their use between (*) 11pm and 7am, with exceptions for celebrations including Diwali and Chinese New Year. For ten points, name these objects which typically prompt choruses of 'ooh' and 'aah' when they are let off on the 5th of November.
tossups.answer: fireworks <HO>

tossups.question: An extravagant xylophone solo features in a Gustav Peter piece written in memory of one of these places. Henry Fillmore never revealed to his conservative father that he wrote music for these places, whilst the euphonium is prominent in a 1913 piece by (*) Karl King composed for one of these places. The best known work of Julius Fučík has become associated with these places, where it may be performed as a screamer under the name “Thunder and Blazes”. For 10 points, name these places where “Entry of the Gladiators” might accompany the shenanigans of clowns or acrobats.
tossups.answer: circuses [accept fairgrounds; accept fairs; prompt on theatres] <HO>

tossups.question: The only solo divertissement in Ashton’s Les Patineurs is for a dancer wearing this colour. This colour is also worn by a male dancer who performs 20 entrechats six to open a pas de deux with Florine. An opera character named for this colour asks a woman “are you afraid?” before a (*) “blood motif” is heard. One musical piece named for this colour is used during the docking sequence in 2001: A Space Odyssey, while another piece named for this colour was inspired by a train ride to Boston and opens with a 17-note clarinet glissando. For 10 points, name this colour which titles a Rhapsody by George Gershwin.
tossups.answer: blue [accept Blue Boy, Bluebird, Bluebeard, Blue Danube, Rhapsody in Blue] <EJW>

tossups.question: One eusocial animal in this order has a body temperature around 32 degrees, which is thought to contribute to their disregard for the Gompertz law of aging. Cre-Lox recombination was developed for one animal in this order. Martin Evans injected embryonic stem cells from these animals into blastocysts to create chimeric (*) “knockout” variants of animals in this order. Weil’s disease is most commonly spread by the urine of animals in this order. For 10 points, name this largest order of mammals which contains naked mole rats and mice.
tossups.answer: Rodentia [or Rodents, prompt on rats or mice] <EM>

tossups.question: A group of 250 volunteers who took part in this event was led by Charles Latour Rogier. The Ten Days’ Campaign tried to reverse this event, which was partly a reaction to the language policies of King William I, and Talleyrand proposed a partition plan for the area involved (*) at the London Conference. This event began after riots during a performance of Auber’s grand opera La muette de Portici, and led to the installation of King Leopold I as the first king of the country involved. For 10 points, name this event in which freedom from the Netherlands was won by the Flemings and Walloons.
tossups.answer: The Belgian revolution/revolt/uprising [also accept the independence of Belgium or Belgian secession (from the Netherlands); prompt on partial answers] <JK>

tossups.question: In one novel, a woman who works in one of these places has an endless stomach and has sex with a man who owns a unicorn skull. Another novella set in a “strange” one of these places features a man who dresses up as a sheep and makes incredibly delicious donuts. In one novel, the transgender Oshima works in one of these places; while he lives and works in one of these places, (*) Kafka dreams of sleeping with his mother and reads 1001 Nights and the complete works of Natsume Soseki. Prominent in the works of Haruki Murakami, for 10 points, name these places from which one can borrow books.
tossups.answer: libraries [do not accept or prompt on “bookshop”] <Theo>

tossups.question: This book compares salvation coming to the Gentiles to wild olive branches being grafted onto a cultivated tree. After comparing the sin of one man, Adam, to the righteousness of one man, Jesus, this book urges readers to “offer your bodies as living sacrifices.” Chapter (*) 8 of this book states, “there is no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus” and asks “if God is with us, then who can be against us?” According to this book, “the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life”. For 10 points, name this epistle of St Paul, the first in the New Testament.
tossups.answer: Epistle to the Romans <LC>

tossups.question: The second book in Charles McCarry’s Paul Christopher series sees the protagonist travel to Vietnam in order to investigate this event, which is considered as a downhill motor race in a J.G. Ballard short story. In James Ellroy’s American Tabloid, two heroin thieves arrange this event in Miami, only to realise it is happening in (*) Texas. Nicholas Branch is an archivist compiling a secret account of this event in Don DeLillo’s novel Libra. A time traveller attempts to prevent this event in a 2011 novel by Stephen King titled for the date this event took place. For 10 points, name this event, which is the subject of King’s 11/22/63.
tossups.answer: the assassination of John F. Kennedy [accept the Kennedy assassination; accept any answer indicating that John F. Kennedy was once alive and was then shot dead] <HO>

tossups.question: In many cases, this function of A is equal to the trace of rho-times-A, where rho is the density matrix. For time-independent Q, this function of the commutator of Q and the Hamiltonian is ih-bar times the time derivative of this function of Q. The time derivative of this function of position is proportional to this function of momentum, according to (*) Ehrenfest’s theorem. For an operator Q, this function is given by the integral of ‘psi-star-Q-psi’ over the reals. For 10 points, name this value of a quantum mechanical operator, which is its average over many repeated trials.
tossups.answer: Expectation value [or expected value; generously prompt on mean, average, I think] <JK>

tossups.question: In one work, this poet wrote that the title concept was “a common topic on / the Transatlantic boats”, and asked whether it would “alter my life altogether”. This poet noted that “we, the inconstant ones, are constantly homesick for” the title landscape in one work, and in another poem, he described how a certain event (*) “was not an important failure”. That work by this author of “In Praise of Limestone” opens “About suffering they were never wrong, the old Masters.” The author of a poem asking to “stop all the clocks”, for 10 points, name this poet of “Musee des Beaux Arts” and “Funeral Blues”.
tossups.answer: Wystan Hugh Auden <JK>

tossups.question: At this battle, a chariot charge was defeated by Agrianian javelin throwers, even though their opponents had flattened the ground before the fight. During this battle, soldiers attempted to rescue the Queen Mother Sisygambis, but she refused to come with them. The right wing of one army in this battle was commanded by (*) Bessus, the satrap of Bactria. In the fiercest part of this battle, sixty hetairoi [het-ay-roi] were killed, and their future commander Hephaestion was wounded. Entering Babylon in triumph soon after, for 10 points, name this decisive 331BC victory over Darius III for Alexander the Great..
tossups.answer: Gaugamela [accept the Battle of Arbela] <JS>

tossups.question: The title of a Gerald Marwell and Ruth Ames study that empirically tested incidence of this behavior asks “Economists [do this], Does Anyone Else?” The need for groups to minimize this behavior is central to Mancur Olson’s The Logic of Collective Action. Elinor Ostrom showed that clear norms can prevent this behavior and (*) and thus avert a situation caused by it first formulated by Garrett Hardin. This behavior causes the Tragedy of the Commons. For 10 points, name this behavior, in which one elects to benefit from public goods with no effort.
tossups.answer: free riding [or being a free rider; prompt on the tragedy of the commons before mentioned or on answers like overusing public/collective resourses with “which is caused by people doing what specific action?”] <JG>

tossups.question: The B2FH paper posited that the p-processes take place during this other process, and Bethe and Wilson proposed the astrophysical “convective overturn” model of this process. Photodisintegration can lead to this process, as can the consumption of gamma rays by pair production. The binding energy of (*) nickel-56 and iron-56 cause them to accumulate rather than fuse, leading to this process when electron degeneracy pressure can no longer support a star’s core. For 10 points, name this process that ends the life of stars of at least 8 solar masses, explosively.
tossups.answer: Type-II Supernovae [prompt on supernova; also accept core-collapse supernovae and equivalents until “core” and prompt thereafter; also accept any of Type Ib, Type Ic, Type IIL, Type IIP, Type IIn, or Type IIb Supernovae, just do NOT accept or prompt on “Type Ia supernovae” or anything involving a “white dwarf”] <JG>

tossups.question: This paper published the controversial David Low cartoon called Morning After the day after the coronation of Elizabeth II. C. P. Scott wrote an essay for the centenary of this paper in which he used the phrase “Comment is free, but facts are sacred”. Private Eye originated a nickname for this paper based on its reputation for frequent (*) typographical errors. In 2018, this newspaper change to a tabloid format from the Berliner format it had used since 2005. For 10 points, name this left-leaning newspaper originally published in Manchester.
tossups.answer: The Guardian

tossups.question: A 1991 episode of this TV series was banned by the BBC for using the words “Perestroika” and “Glasnost”, which were seen to promote Communist ideology. That controversy spawned a meme in which this show’s central character declares “I will make Stalin look like a fucking Anarchist.” In another episode that was also removed from British TV, that character (*) dreams about his mattress being eaten by a giant walrus. Carlo Bonomi created the gibberish ‘language’ used in this show, including its protagonist’s characteristic cry of “Noot noot!” For 10 points, name this Swiss-British clay animation about the title penguin.
tossups.answer: Pingu <Tom>

tossups.question: In 1856, the artist Francis Oliphant published a plea for work in this medium. Ford Madox Brown designed a work in this medium showing King René's Honeymoon. A series of works in this medium depicting the story of Tristram and Isolde were designed by (*) a team of artists including Dante Gabriel Rossetti and William Morris. Augustus Pugin's The Temptation of Eve is a work in this medium in West Tofts, Norfolk. For 10 points, name this medium, works in which by Edward Burne-Jones can be found in the windows of ecclesiastical buildings nationwide.
tossups.answer: stained glass [accept painted glass; prompt on glass] <HO>

tossups.question: Sextus Empiricus tripartitioned this idea and held that two parts did not exist, while C.D. Broad’s “growing block view” of it holds that only two of those parts exist. Michael Dummett advocated a “constructive” view of this idea in an article that asks if it is a type of “continuum.” The (*) “A-series” and “B-series” descriptions of this idea are held to be contradictory in a J.M.E. McTaggart work advocating the “Unreality” of this concept. For 10 points, name this idea, divided by Augustine in Book XI of Confessions into forms past, present, and to come.
tossups.answer: Time [prompt on tenses; anti-prompt on any specific tense or things like past, present, and future; do not accept or prompt on “the universe”] <HO> Bonuses:

bonuses.leadin: Humanity is really good at making flightless birds go extinct. For 10 points each:
parts: The most famous cause célèbre of extinct Indian Ocean birds is, of course, this unfortunately ground-dwelling inhabitant of Mauritius, who died out within a few decades of human arrival in the 17th century.
Related to the dodo was this equally ground-dwelling inhabitant of Rodrigues, who had evolved club-like wings with which they could beat each other up when competing for territory.

This family of ratites that inhabited Madagascar are also all thought to have gone extinct by the 17th century. It included Aepyornis maximus, thought to have possibly been the largest and heaviest bird that ever lived.

bonuses.leadin: While this man only had one attempt at filmmaking, Michael Colgan was more successful in bringing his 19 plays to the screen. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Irish playwright of the “Theatre of the Absurd”. In Colgan’s series, Barry McGovern and Johnny Murphy played Vladimir and Estragon, characters from this writer’s Waiting for Godot.
This character from another Beckett work was portrayed by David Thewlis on film. He was taken in as a child by the blind Hamm, played by Michael Gambon, and is unable to sit down.

While originally written for Patrick Magee, John Hurt took on the title role in this one-act play by Beckett. It is set on the character’s 69th birthday, which he spends giving his thoughts on the last 12 months.

bonuses.leadin: Historical events that feature in this novel include the anti-Muslim riots in Gujarat in 2002 and the insurgency in Kashmir. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel which follows the activist Tilo and the hijra Anjum, the latter of whom creates the Jannat Guest House in a graveyard in Delhi.

In this other novel by the author of The Ministry of Utmost Happiness, set mostly in Kerala, Sophie Mol drowns while on a boat with the twins Estha and Rahel, who commit incest at the end of this novel.

The God of Small Things and The Ministry of Utmost Happiness are the only two novels written by this Indian author, who devoted much of the 20 years between their publication to controversial political advocacy.

bonuses.leadin: The mother of a ruler of this city berated him for “crying like a woman for what you could not defend like a man.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this southern Spanish city, famous for the Alhambra Palace. Its conquest from the Nasrid dynasty by Ferdinand and Isabella marks the end of the Reconquista.

This last Nasrid ruler of Granada surrendered the city peacefully to Ferdinand and Isabella after a Castilian siege. His last look at the city, to exactly zero sympathy from his mother, has been called “The Moor’s Last Sigh.”

Unlike most other smaller Muslim principalities after the fall of the Spanish Umayyads, the Nasrid Kingdom of Granada is usually referred to as an “emirate” and not as one of these states. This term literally means “faction.”

bonuses.leadin: Their namesake effect arises due to their increased preorganisation relative to acyclic analogues. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these molecules which are known for containing large rings.
A macrocycle can be threaded onto an axle to produce one of these interlocked compounds which often form the basis for molecular machines.
An important class of biological macrocycles are porphyrin rings, one of which binds iron in this protein that transports oxygen in blood.

bonuses.leadin: This disease presented with skin pustules in a centrifugal distribution, which distinguished it from chickenpox. For 10 points each:
answers: Variola [accept variola major or variola minor]
parts: Name this disease, for which Edward Jenner used material from a cowpox-infected maid as a vaccination. It has since been presumed eradicated.
This “dumbbell-shaped” virus caused smallpox. It is a double-stranded DNA virus of the order Orthopoxvirus.
This eradicated viral disease of cattle had its last confirmed case in 2011. Its name derives from the German for "cattle-plague".

bonuses.leadin: This painter depicted a moonlit sea formed from the wreckage of German aircraft in Totes Meer. For 10 points each:
answers: The First World War [or the Great War; or World War One] <HO>
parts: Name this artist, who often depicted bare tree trunks standing in churned up battlefields, such as in Wire, The Menin Road, and We Are Making a New World.
This artist showed a battalion of Canadian troops marching through a similarly battle-scarred landscape in The Conquerors, and depicted a platoon of British troops in The Kensingtons at Laventie.
Both Nash and Kennington were commissioned by the Department of Information to serve as official artists during this war. William Orpen's Dead Germans in a Trench was also created during this war.

bonuses.leadin: William of Malmesbury rather spuriously claims that this thinker’s students stabbed him to death with their pens. For 10 points each:
answers: John Duns Scotus [also accept Johann Duns]
parts: Name this thinker who made a notable translation of Pseudo-Dionysius the Areopagite and divides nature into four parts along axes of creating and being created in his pantheistic work Periphyseon.

This later thinker formulated the concept of “univocity of being” and called the property that makes a thing what it is its “haecceity” or “thisness.” This thinker was often known as “Doctor Subtilis.”
John Duns Scotus wrote a major commentary on Lombard’s Four Books of Sentences, a major resource in this style of philosophy and educational method that flourished in medieval European universities.

bonuses.leadin: This mathematician’s PhD thesis gave asymptotics for the number of simple closed geodesics on a hyperbolic surface. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Iranian mathematician, whose characterisation of moduli spaces with Alex Eskin was hailed as the theorem of the decade in dynamics, and who tragically died of breast cancer in 2017, aged just 40.

Mirzakhani was the first female mathematician to win this award, given for “outstanding contributions in mathematics” to researchers under 40, and (like the Abel Prize) considered a ‘Nobel Prize in mathematics’.
Much of Mirzakhani’s work was on these surfaces, which are 1-dimensional complex manifolds. The complex logarithm can be defined continuously on one of these surfaces.

bonuses.leadin: Orchestras were typical in Nazi concentration camps, although there was something incongruous about the light music against a background of flames and smoke. For 10 points each:
parts: This renowned concert violinist conducted the Women’s Orchestra of Auschwitz. Portrayed by Jane Alexander in Arthur Miller’s Playing for Time, she was the niece of Gustav Mahler.
Sunday concerts for other women prisoners sometimes included these lively pieces. Originally composed for piano four hands, this set of 21 pieces was adapted from national themes by Johannes Brahms.

Along with “Fairwell”, this name is often given to Étude No. 3 in E Major by Frédéric Chopin. Playing this banned piece, as arranged for voice and orchestra by Rosé, expressed resistance against the Nazis.

bonuses.leadin: You’re Ellie Warner, and you have decided, against all good judgment, to learn Polish. Answer some questions about some of the linguistic phenomena you will encounter, for 10 points each:
answers: grammatical cases <EJW> (EJW note: i did not write the lead in)
parts: One difficulty is that Polish orthography has some key differences from English. For example, this letter in Polish represents the voiced labiodental fricative and not the voiced labiovelar glide like in English.

Pronunciation is difficult too, due to consonant clusters that arose in Slavic languages after the loss of these sounds. Russian still uses the Cyrillic letters for these sounds to indicate if a preceding consonant is palatalised.

Learning to construct a Polish sentence is also tricky, since it requires using seven of these grammatical categories, like the instrumental, locative, and dative, which determine morphosyntactic agreement.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the Einstein Field Equations. For 10 points each:
parts: The Einstein Field Equations describe gravitation in this theory, which relates gravity to the curvature of spacetime.

Birkhoff’s theorem shows that this man’s solution to the Einstein field equations is the most general spherically symmetric one. This man also names the distance from the centre of a black hole to its event horizon.
This Dutch scientist names the maximally symmetric vacuum solution of the Einstein field equations that has a negative cosmological constant.

bonuses.leadin: The N-linked form of this process takes place in the rough endoplasmic reticulum. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process where a small sugar is added to a protein to modify it.
This polyprenol lipid’s phosphate functions as a membrane anchor, and its presence is necessary for N-linked glycosylation.
Instead of the rough endoplasmic reticulum, O-linked glycosylation takes place in this other organelle which consists of a stack of flattened cisternae.

bonuses.leadin: Lots of interesting things happened on islands in Greek mythology, for some reason. For 10 points each:
parts: Leto was only able to give birth to these two twin deities upon reaching the floating island of Delos, the only place which was not firm land.
The nymph Calypso lived on this island, where she detained Odysseus for seven years. Maltese folklore associates it with the modern island of Gozo.

While hiding Europa on Crete, Zeus commissioned this bronze automaton, which Theseus narrowly escaped, to protect her. He was apparently killed by the Argonauts when Medea managed to get a nail out of his heel.

bonuses.leadin: One song on this album opens with the lyrics ‘Look up here, I’m in heaven/I’ve got scars that can’t be seen’, which became all the more poignant when the performer died a day after the album’s release. For 10 points each:
answers: Blackstar [accept descriptions of a picture of a black star as that is technically the album’s name]
Mount Erie [accept Phil Elverum, do not accept or prompt on “The Microphones”]
Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds <Theo>
parts: Name this 2016 art rock album, the swan song of David Bowie.

Potentially the most harrowing album about death in recent memory is A Crow Looked At Me, a raw depiction of how this artist was lain low by grief following the passing of his wife. This artist is also known for the album Dawn.

This Australian artist had apparently written all but one of the songs on the album Skeleton Tree before the death of his son, but tracks such as Jesus Alone and I Need You would seem to directly allude to the incident.

bonuses.leadin: In this poem, its author seemed to prophesy his own death with lines like “I must first be lost in fatal tides”. For 10 points each:
answers: Voyages [accept specific parts of the poem, I-VI, as long as Voyages is mentioned]
Hart Crane (prompt on Crane; do not accept Stephen Crane)
parts: Name this poem inspired by Emil Oppfer, which opens by describing how “above the fresh ruffles of the surf, bright striped urchins flay each other with sand” and ends “it is the unbetrayable reply/whose accent no farewell can know”.
Voyages is a poem by this American poet, who attempted to outdo TS Eliot’s The Waste Land in his own masterpiece, The Bridge.
The Bridge is titled in honour of a real-life bridge, which connects Manhattan to this most populous borough of New York. Walt Whitman described “crossing” this area’s “ferry” in an earlier poem.

bonuses.leadin: For your ultra-hardcore Hugh Oxlade British historiography bonus, name some revolutions which may or may not have occurred in Britain in the 17th century. For 10 points each:
answers: The Industrious Revolution [accept industriousness given the title of Muldrew’s study; prompt on descriptive answers like people worked more and/or played less] <HO>
parts: Eric Kerridge argued that this revolution was over by 1673, although this has been challenged by Robert Allen and Mark Overton. The introduction of turnips to fallow fields is often seen as a crucial aspect of this revolution.

P.G.M. Dickson, Henry Roseveare, and Douglass North and Barry Weingast have investigated this revolution, seemingly set in by the Glorious Revolution. Its innovations included the 1693 tontine and limited liability set-ups.

Jan de Vries used Akira Hayami’s concept of this revolution to explain consumer demand in Europe from 1650. Craig Muldrew linked food and energy to the “creation” of its namesake shift in work and leisure patterns.

bonuses.leadin: After this chain ran an immigration sting on its own workers, activists released thousands of cockroaches and locusts into two of their branches in protest. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this British chain. Tom Byng founded this restaurant chain in 2007, inspired by the burgers at the Silver Top diner in Rhode Island – though contrary to popular belief, it is not actually named after a poet.

Byron have recently sought help from KPMG to carry out one of these restructuring plans to save the business. Toys R Us and Jamie’s Italian have also used these plans, which let insolvent firms negotiate solutions with creditors.

One of the creditors to back the CVA for Toys R Us was this statutory fund chaired by Alan Rubenstein. This organisation is currently poised to take on DB schemes for the collapsed construction company Carillion.

bonuses.leadin: Mark Twain famously said that he came in with this object in 1835, and that he expected to go out with it in 1910, which he indeed did. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this celestial object, which is visible from Earth roughly every 76 years.

This astronomer’s life was also appropriately bookended by Halley’s comet from 1835 to 1910. Though he was key in reinterpreting Eudoxus’ work, he is now best remembered for alleged ‘canals’ he saw on the surface of Mars.
This French author’s life was similarly bookended, though from 1910 to 1986. After an early life of vagabondage, he settled down to write plays like The Maids and The Balcony.

bonuses.leadin: Under this system, the Mughal empire gave many nobles and officials the rights to a jagir, or revenue for land, rather than the land itself. For 10 points each:
answers: Abu’l Fath Jalal-ud-din Muhammad Akbar [accept either underlined portion]
parts: Give this term which describes both the overarching system of rights to collect money and administer land in Mughal India, introduced in 1572 under the supervision of Raja Todar Mal, and the system’s various ranks.

This Mughal emperor introduced the Mansabdar system. Known as “the Great,” he abolished the jizya tax, enforced sulh-i kul or “total peace” between different religions, and, allegedly, founded his own syncretic faith.

Marshall Hodgson coined the term “gunpowder empire” to describe the Mughals, Ottomans, and this empire. This empire came to power with the help of the Qizilbash and began the conversion of Persia to Shī‘a Islam.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about Shinto shrines:
answers: the honden [also accept shinden or shōden]
the Ise Grand Shrine [also accept the Ise Jingū; also accept Naikū and Gekū and prompt on answers that give only one] <EJW>
parts: The kanjō ceremony transfers these spirits central to the religion from one shrine to another. All Shinto shrines are constructed to house one or more of these animistic deities. Examples include Susanoo and Amaterasu.

The most sacred part of a Shinto shrine complex is this building. Go-shintai, physical repositories for kami, are kept inside this main sanctuary, which is typically in the back of the shrine and kept closed to the public.

One of the holiest and arguably most famous Shinto shrines is this complex in Mie Prefecture. It supposedly holds one of the Imperial Regalia, the sacred mirror Yata no Kagami, and is completely rebuilt every twenty years.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about attempts to restrict legal recognition of same-sex marriages prior to Obergefell v. Hodges, For 10 points each:
answers: DOMA [or the Defense of Marriage Act]
parts: An attempt by lawmakers to “protect” the family from legal same-sex marriages was this 1996 act, signed into law by President Clinton. It notably let states refuse to recognize same-sex marriages valid in other states.

DOMA was struck down in this case named for a New York LGBT activist. It ruled DOMA a violation of the Fifth Amendment, but did not explicitly specify the scrutiny level appropriate to same-sex marriage cases.
An earlier move to ban same-sex marriage was Proposition 8, a ballot measure in this US state.

bonuses.leadin: This work’s title character describes seeing “freely under all the heavens” to his son Walter, explaining that “the corn grows in long, beautiful valleys and the land looks like a garden.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this work about the rivalry between the tyrant Gessler and the title character. The title character ultimately shoots Gessler with a bow and arrow, upon which the liberated peasants call him their “shield and saviour”.
Wilhelm Tell is a play by this German author, a Weimar Classicist like his friend Johann Wolfgang von Goethe.

This other Schiller play was left as an incomplete fragment upon his death. This play is based on the life of the title character, who was briefly Russian Tsar in 1604, and declares to the Polish diet that he is the son of Ivan the Terrible.

bonuses.leadin: The keyboard players who featured on Bitches Brew achieved considerable success in their own right. For 10 points each:
parts: This pianist was the third credited electric pianist on Bitches Brew. His notable subsequent releases include the album Return to Forever, and a set of duets with fellow pianist Herbie Hancock.
This musician, who more typically performed on Hammond organ, was the second credited electric pianist on Bitches Brew. He is best known for his earlier solo release Unity.

Austrian keyboard player Joe Zawinul wrote the album opener “Pharaoh's Dance”. He later co-founded this jazz group, which included bassist Jaco Pastorius and released the album I Sing the Body Electric as well as the standard “Birdland”.
